subject: Re: JUnit 3.5 & Ant 1.3

messageBody:
--- In junit@y..., Vitezslav Stejskal <vitezslav.stejskal@c...> wrote:
>
> There is a several things you have to keep in
> mind when using Ant:
>
> * all tasks are instantiated during the parsing time, even if they
> will never be launched

Not entirely true. If Ant cannot instantiate a task at parser time,
it will try again at execution time. This is to support building
and using a task in the same process.

> * the above rule has an exception - tasks placed in the
> package org.apache.tools.ant are *always* loaded using
> the system classpath

Are always *tried* to be loaded from the system classpath. If Ant
cannot find it there, it will use the classpath you've supplied
with the taskdef.

> So far I see two options:
> * put junit.jar on the system's claspath

should work well.

> * create new class derived from the
> org.apache.tools.ant.taskdef.optional.junit.JUnitTask,

Not necessary. Option three

* make sure the optional task you want to use is *not* in the system
classpath (remove it from optional.jar) but in the classpath you
supply with the taskdef tag.


Stefan
